Award.AwardTitle: Gigapixel Widefield Super-Resolved Structured Illumination Microscopy

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1403905
Izatt, Joseph A.
Title: Gigapixel Widefield Super-Resolved Structured Illumination Microscopy

Significance:
An award is made to Duke University to perform research to improve microscopy technology for imaging biological specimens over wide fields of view at high resolution. Many widely used applications of microscopy such as in cell biology and histology require frequent switching between a wide field-of-view (FOV) to identify tissue features and locations of interest, and narrow FOV to image at cellular and sub-cellular resolution. The need to manually zoom in and out is time consuming and incompatible with improvements in modern digital image capture and review methodology. This research addresses and provides a solution for this problem

Technical Description:
The PI will develop a novel spatially structured illumination element to be placed in close proximity to the sample to multiplex high spatial frequency image content into the detection aperture of a wide field of view microscope objective. The project will advance the state of the art in coherent super-resolution imaging technology. The project will include extending modern super-resolution imaging techniques from their current focus on nanometer scale imaging to broader applications in biological research and clinical laboratory diagnostics. The project will also support the education and scientific training of engineering students from Duke and elsewhere at multiple levels. The project will comprise the Ph.D. dissertation research of a Duke biomedical engineering student, and Duke undergraduate engineering students will have opportunities to participate in the research through independent study. Additionally, three underrepresented engineering students recruited into Duke's Research Experience for Undergraduate program will each spend a summer assisting with this research as well as participating in related training and outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project were to develop novel optical microscopy technologies for super-resolution imaging with potential applications in clinical diagnostics. This was accomplished by developing and extending the technique of structured illumination (SI) microscopy for sub-diffraction imaging across a wide field-of-view (FOV), as well as for imaging of non-fluorescent samples including magnitude and phase of coherently illuminated samples in both transmission and reflection.

In the first project objective a prototype fluorescent SI imager was implemented to image across ultra-wide FOV at sub-micron scale resolution for gigapixel imaging. To accomplish this, we designed a novel structured element comprised of chrome bars printed onto glass, which was placed in close proximity to the sample. This approach eliminated the limit of the system's numerical aperture on the spatial frequency of the structured element, allowing additional higher-order spatial harmonics to pass through the system. We tested this approach both in simulation and in a protptype optical design, and were able to achieve a factor of 2x resolution improvement between the wide-field and SIM reconstructed images.

In the second project objective, we developed a technique to extend widefield SI microscopy for simultaneous diffracted, quantitative-phase, and fluorescent imaging of biological samples. In this work, we developed a novel approach for single-shot, spatial-frequency-multiplexed microscopy via off-axis interference as a novel wide-field imaging technique that enables true simultaneous multimodal and multichannel wide-field imaging. We prototyped an experimental system which used spatial frequency multiplexing to combine one brightfield, one quantitative-phase, and two fluorescent imaging channels to allow single-camera, simultaneous multichannel imaging. Using this system, we were able to experimentally demonstrate this technique for single-camera, simultaneous two-channel fluorescence and one-channel quantitative-phase imaging for fluorescent microspheres and fixed cells stained for F-actin and nuclear fluorescence. This work was published in the journal Optics Letters.

Also as part of our second objective, we extended multimodal SI imaging to sub-diffraction, 3D resolved quantitative phase and fluorescence microscopy. Following theoretical development of a framework for SI-enabled three-dimensional (3D) quantitative phase sub-diffraction imaging, we designed and constructed an optical system and demonstrated this capability with calibrated samples. Image analysis confirmed enhanced lateral and axial resolutions over diffraction-limited quantitative phase imaging, and established striking parallels between coherent SI and conventional optical diffraction tomography. We then modified the system to achieve 3D sub-diffraction, multimodal QP/fluorescent visualization, and used it to validate sub-diffraction imaging performance in A549 lung cancer cells fluorescently tagged with Alexa Fluor 488 dye for F-actin localization. These results, published in the journal Biomedical Optics Express, demonstrated that SI has a unique utility in studying biological phenomena with significant molecular, biophysical, and biochemical components.

As our third project objective, building upon the striking parallel we noticed in the second objective between coherent SI and optical diffraction tomography, we extended this concept to allow for full 3D refractive index tomography. Refractive index (RI) is an important optical property of biological objects that is often exploited to visualize endogenous biological contrast with microscopy techniques that specialize in label-free imaging. Standard examples of such microscopy techniques, which are heavily used in the biological sciences include phase-contrast and differential interference microscopies. Unfortunately, these techniques do not generate distributions that can be quantitatively associated with RI, and thus only allow qualitative biological analysis. We demonstrated that SI microscopy can also allow 3D reconstruction of RI distributions when operated in the coherent imaging realm. Our experimental setup generated SI patterns using broadband illumination with a spatial light modulator, and detected angle dependent sample diffraction through a common-path, off-axis interferometer with no moving components. Standard diffraction tomotraphy reconstruction was used to combine these computed electric field maps into a 3D RI distribution of the sample. In work published in the journal Optica, we demonstrated 3D quantitative RI reconstructions in human breast (MCF-7) and colorectal (HT-29) adenocarcinoma cells.

The broader scientific impacts of the project were to extend modern super-resolution imaging techniques from their current focus on nanometer scale imaging to broader applications in biological research and clinical laboratory diagnostics. The project also supported the education and scientific training of engineering students from Duke and elsewhere at multiple levels. The project comprised the bulk of the dissertation research of one Duke Biomedical Engineering Ph.D. student. The project also supported productive research experiences for one outstanding Duke undergraduate as an independent study project, and for one outstanding undergraduate from the University of North Carolina as a Research Experiences for Undergraduate summer project. Both of these research experiences resulting in inclusion of these students as authors on presentations at national scientific conferences, and solidified their plans for continuing with STEM related careers.
